stem: An 8-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician's office for vomiting and 'extreme sleepiness.' Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two appropriate nursing actions, and two parameters to monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Assessment for potential hydrocephalus or meningitis.

Background: Infant born at 34 weeks gestation with a history of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) at birth.

Assessment: At 14:00, the infant is lethargic and exhibits a high-pitched cry when touched. Anterior fontanel is tense and bulging. 'Sunset' eyes are noted.

Recommendation: Stat neurological imaging, urgent head circumference check, and continuous neurological monitoring.

tabs.title: Growth Chart Analytics
tabs.content: Head Circumference: 98th percentile (Previously 50th percentile). Jump occurred over 2 months.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: Heart Rate: 140 bpm; Respiratory Rate: 40 breaths/min; Oxygen Saturation: 98% on room air; Temperature: 37.5°C (99.5°F); Blood Pressure: 90/60 mmHg

actionOptions.text: Maintain the infant's head in a neutral, midline position.
Measure and record head circumference daily.
Encourage the parents to rock the infant vigorously for comfort.
Place the infant in a prone position for sleep.

parameterOptions.text: Fontanel tension and presence of 'sunset' eyes.
Infant's level of consciousness and feeding ability.
Presence of a positive Brudzinski sign.

rationale.correct: The infant is showing classic signs of Pediatric Increased ICP (c2): Bulging/tense fontanels, separated sutures, 'sunset' eyes, and a high-pitched cry. The rapid jump in head circumference (growth chart) further confirms expansion. Priority actions are to prevent further pressure spikes by keeping the head midline (a1) to ensure venous drainage and tracking the growth trend (a2). Monitoring the fontanels (p1) and responsiveness (p2) is the primary method of evaluation.
clinicalPearls: Bulging fontanels = Increased Pressure; Sunken fontanels = Dehydration.
The 'Sunset' eye sign is caused by pressure on cranial nerves that control eye movement.
In infants, the head CAN expand because the sutures are not fused, which is why head circumference is the most important measurement.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking a bulging fontanel is 'normal' when an infant is crying.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: A fontanel can bulge briefly when crying or coughing, but if it is bulging and tense while the infant is QUIET, it is always a medical emergency.

mnemonic.title: Baby ICP
mnemonic.expansion: B-Bulging fontanel. A-Abnormal Sunset eyes. B-Big head (Growth). Y-Yelling (High-pitched cry).
